channel.title: Krista L. DeStasio
channel.description: Recent content on Krista L. DeStasio

item.title: About
item.description: I am a scientific researcher and aspiring programmer interested in creating usable interfaces through data driven insights. While I have learned a great deal of programing through self-instruction, I decided in Fall of 2019 to attend Lane Community College for formal training in computer programming and am currently studying to earn an Associate of Applied Science in Computer Programming. I earned an M.S. in Psychology from the University of Oregon where I was a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow in the Social and Affective Neuroscience Lab.

item.title: Resume
item.description: Krista L. DeStasio, M.S. E-mail: kdestasio@gmail.com GitHub: https://github.com/kdestasio Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/kdestasio/ SKILLS Proficiency: R, R Shiny, Git/GitHub, MacOS, Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, Statistics Familiarity: Python, MATLAB, HTML/CSS, JSON, Linux CentOS & RHEL, Excel Exposure: C#, SQL, Oracle, Singularity, Docker, SLURM RELEVANT EXPERIENCE GRADUATE LEVEL RESEARCHER Social and Affective Neuroscience Lab, University of Oregon 2016 â€“ 2019 Developed computer tasks in PsychoPy to present visual stimuli and collect participant responses https://github.com/kdestasio/child_task and adapted extant MATLAB tasks for use in new studies based on user feedback.

item.title: Clustering Analysis of Dot Probe Data
item.description: This post walks through an exploratory k-means clustering analysis as applied to numerical data from a dot probe task. Steps to preprocess and analyze the data are discussed and the results are presented through visualizations, as well as a discussion of the results. All code used in the analysis and in the production of this blog post is available at https://github.com/kdestasio/hc_analysis. For additional resources on clustering, see the references section at the bottom of the post.

item.title: R Best Practices
item.description: When learning to write code for research projects, it can be overwhelming to figure out how to set-up a project and the novice programmer may not yet have the experience necessary to forsee potential pitfalls of a given, seemingly inconsequential decision. This post provides a discussion of best practices1 for developing code-based projects and for writing R code in a research setting with an eye toward proactively avoiding common pitfalls.
